quoteLast: when Paul Harley rang me up. Since we had parted in the early morning I had had no word from him, and I was all anxiety to tell him of the quaint little romance which unknown to us had had its setting in the room above.
title: Tales of Chinatown
author: Rohmer, Sax, 1883-1959

quoteFirst: The vessel was very much crowded, having the mails of four days on board, and the accumulation of four days' passengers. It was very cold, and I was, as usual, sea-sick. I went on shore
quoteLast: , and was conducted to an hotel in the upper town, all those of the lower town, which are the best, being full. I took under my protection an English lady proceeding to her husband at Havre-de-Grace.
title: Peregrine in France: A Lounger's Journal, in Familiar Letters to His Friend
author: Bromet, William, 1783-1850

quoteFirst: A prolonged siesta was the first operation; a large, cool, dark room being infinitely preferable for that purpose than the stuffy little cabins on board the ship. After the siesta there would be a couple of hours strenuous lawn-tennis, then a very late dinner, and finally a prolonged visit to one of the music-halls of the town, which began their evening's business
quoteLast: and did not bring it to an end until any hour in the morning, and finally back to the ship for two or three hours' sleep before the "labours" of the next day began.
title: Looking Back
author: Fortescue, Seymour John, Sir, 1856-1942

quoteFirst: I asked Red Bear if it was so, and he replied that a rumor to that effect was current among the tribes, but he did not know whether it was true or not. quoteFirst: Some weeks passed and the sun had scarcely risen when Beharilal sat in the ota in front of his house at his daily business, which began as soon as his teeth were cleaned and ended
quoteLast: . The place was not tidy. Two or three mats were spread on the floor, a spare one was rolled up in a corner, several pairs of shoes were on the steps, umbrellas leaned against the wall, handles downwards, and a large chatty of drinking water stood beside them.

quoteFirst: From this time till the 24th of the same month, when he expired,
quoteLast: , in the 67th year of his age; his principal employment was reading the Scriptures and conversing with his friends; and over his remains, which were accompanied to the churchyard by the Earl of Morton, the Regent, and a number of other noblemen, and people of all ranks, his lordship pronounced the following eulogium: “Here lies a man, who in his life never feared the face of man; who hath been often threatened with dag and dagger, but yet hath ended his days in peace and honour.

quoteFirst: “I was taken into a large room where there were neither hangings nor bed; that which was brought in
quoteLast: was of Chinese taffeta, not at all the thing for winter furniture.  I slept very well, which must not be attributed to stout-heartedness, because misfortune has naturally that effect upon me.

title:
The vigilantes of Montana; Or, popular justice in the Rocky Mountains
Being a correct and impartial narrative of the chase, trial, capture and execution of Henry Plummer's road agent band, together with accounts of the lives and crimes of many of the robbers and desperadoes, the whole being interspersed with sketches of life in the mining camps of the "Far West"
author: Dimsdale, Thos. J. (Thomas Josiah), -1866

quoteFirst: Gentle at first, by noon it is rushing and roaring through the town in a perfect gale, to drop and die away entirely by 4 p.m. By a most convenient arrangement, the land breeze, disagreeably known as "the Undertaker," drops down from the Liguanea Mountains on to the sweltering town
quoteLast: , and continues all through the night. It is this double breeze, from sea by day, from land by night, that renders life in Kingston tolerable. Owing to the sea breeze invariably blowing from the same direction, Jamaicans have the puzzling habit of using "Windward" and "Leeward" as synonyms for East and West.
title: Here, There and Everywhere
author: Hamilton, Frederic, Lord, 1856-1928

quoteFirst: _--Anna and I had a serenade last night from the Academy Glee Club, I think, as their voices sounded familiar. We were awakened by the music,
quoteLast: , quite suddenly and I thought I would step across the hall to the front chamber for a match to light the candle. I was only half awake, however, and lost my bearings and stepped off the stairs and rolled or slid to the bottom.
title:
Village Life in America 1852-1872, Including the Period of the American Civil War

quoteFirst: Minnes being gone to bed, I took Mr. Whitfield, one of the clerks, and walked to the Dock
quoteLast: , and there got a boat and a crew, and rowed down to the guard-ships, it being a most pleasant moonshine evening that ever I saw almost. The guard-ships were very ready to hail us, being no doubt commanded thereto by their Captain, who remembers how I surprised them the last time I was here.
title: Diary of Samuel Pepys — Complete 1663 N.S.
author: Pepys, Samuel, 1633-1703; Braybrooke, Richard Griffin, Baron, 1783-1858 [Editor]; Wheatley, Henry B. (Henry Benjamin), 1838-1917 [Editor]; Bright, Mynors, 1818-1883 [Translator]

quoteFirst: Nevertheless hearest thou not, O reader (for the sound reaches through centuries), in the dead December and January nights, over Nantes Town,—confused noises, as of musketry and tumult, as of rage and lamentation; mingling with the everlasting moan of the Loire waters there? Nantes Town is sunk in sleep; but _Représentant_ Carrier is not sleeping, the wool-capped Company of Marat is not sleeping. Why unmoors that flatbottomed craft, that _gabarre;_
quoteLast: ; with Ninety Priests under hatches? They are going to Belle Isle? In the middle of the Loire stream, on signal given, the gabarre is scuttled; she sinks with all her cargo. “Sentence of Deportation,” writes Carrier, “was executed _vertically_.
title: The French Revolution: A History
author: Carlyle, Thomas, 1795-1881

quoteFirst: The field was surrounded by a low fence and the boys at rest lay in the fence corners. It was a bright starlight September night, no moon visible, but one could distinguish an object some distance beyond. I was on the watch. It was
quoteLast: , when through the still night, I heard foot-steps and the breaking of corn stalks. I listened intently, and the noise ceased.
title:
Memoirs of a Veteran Who Served as a Private in the 60's in the War Between the States
